handDesc.p: KR does not describe the original punctuation marks. This edition prints | and || as shown in KR's edition.

Other palaeographic observations, summarised from Krishna Rao. The writing is very neat and careful, but with innumerable mistakes. Anusvāra is frequently omitted or added superfluously. There are two forms of ja, an open square form (l5, 10) and a later cursive form (l6, 7, 8, 9, 10). The scribe makes a distinction between da and ḍa, notable in l45 where the two are side by side.

projectDesc.p: This project DHARMA has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement no 809994).

prefixDef.p: Public URIs with the prefix bib to point to a Zotero Group Library named ERC-DHARMA whose data are open to the public.
Internal URIs using the part prefix to point to person elements in the DHARMA_IdListMembers_v01.xml file.

div.head: Plates
div.p:
svasti| śrīmatāṁ sakala-bhuvana-saṁstūyamāna-mānavya-sagotrānāṁ harīti-putrānṇāṁ kau
śitī-vara-prasāda-labdha-rājyaānāṁ mātr̥-ganṇa-paripālīitānāṁ svāmi-mahāsena-pādā
nudhyātānāṁ bhagavaṇ-ṇn-nārāyaṇa-prasāda-samāsādita-vara-varaāha-lānnñchanekṣanṇa-kṣa
ṇa-vaśiīkr̥tārāti-maṇḍalānāṁ Aśvamedhāvabhr̥tha-snaāna-pavitr̥rīkr̥ta-vapuṣāṁ cālu
kyānāṁ kulam alanṁkariṣṇoḥ satyāśraya-vallabhendrasya bhrātāD kubja-viṣṇuvarddhana Aṣṭā
daśa varṣaānṇi+. tasya sūnuḥ sakala-lokāśrayo jayasiṁha-vallabhaḥ trayastr̥riṁśad varṣānṇi+.
tasyānujasya Indra-bhaṭṭārakasya pr̥riya-tanayaḥ viṣṇurājaḥ nava varṣānṇi+. tasya sutaṁḥ
maṁgi-dauśarājaḥ pañcaviṁśati varṣānṇi+. tasya putraḥ jayasiṁha-vallabhaḥ trayodaśa va
ṣarṣāṇīi+. tasyānujaḥ dvaimāturaḥ kokkiliḥ ṣaṇ māsāTN+. tasyāgrajaḥ viṣṇuraājaḥ svaānujam uccā
ṭya pañcatr̥riṁśad varṣāṇīi+. tasyātmajaḥ vijayāditya-mahārāja Aṣṭādaśa varṣāṇni+. tasya ta
nayaḥ viṣṇuvarddhanaḥ pañcatr̥riṁśad varṣāṇi dvādaśa-sahasra-pramāṇaṁ venṅgī-maṇḍalaṁ
m anvapālayaNT+. tasya jyeṣṭhaḥ vijayādityaḥ Āditya Iva satatodaya-kariī vindhyāṭa
viīva su-vaṁśa-śatādhāraḥ merur iva suvarnnṇṇa-varnnṇṇīkr̥ta-tanuḥ hara-jaṭā-makuṭa Iva gaṁgā
-rava-pratibandhana-samarttthaḥ surapati-gaja Iva satata-dāna-karī viṣṇur iva ba
li-ripu-matthaṇnaḥ śeṣa-mahānāga Iva bhū-dharaṇa-kṣama-bhujaḥ mahā-vratiīva mahā-śaṁkha
-dhvani-virājanaḥ sakala-gaṁga-kula-garjjaj-jalada-ghaṭa-koṭi-vitrāsana-viśiṣṭa-mā
rutaḥ Api ca

Aṣṭottara-śata-narendreśvara-devaālayānāṁ karttā dvādaśa-varṣa-yuddhaṁ vallabhendra-daṇḍa
-nāyakaiḥ saha bhīma-saḷuke-nāmānaṁ svānujaṁ nirjjitya gr̥hīta-veṁgi-maṇḍalaḥ catvāriṁśa
d varṣāṇi+. tasya sutaḥ|

app.note: KR reports the reading of the seal without śrī, but the honorific may still be present.
KR does not normalise the dental n, which may be a typo in his edition.
KR does not normalise the dental n, which may be a typo in his edition.
KR does not emend the superfluous D, which may be a typo in his edition.

According to KR's note, Lakshmana Rao interpreted some dots above na as a subsequently inserted visarga. KR asserts that the dots are only corrosion, though I do not know how he can be so sure if he edited the plates from impressions while LR had the originals.
KR does not supply da, which thus may be omitted in his edition by mistake.
KR in fact prints ḍandra, clearly a typo in the Devanagari edition.
According to KR's note, śa is not clear and looks like ga. I do not know why then he thinks it is śa. In his discussion he uses the name as dogarāja and equates it to yuvarāja.
KR prints the supplied characters in round parentheses with an asterisk. This may represent illegible and supplied text, since above he uses square brackets and an asterisk for omitted and supplied.
KR's Devanagari edition has वे[न्]गी, emending to veṅgī in a footnote. I assume, but am not sure, that the upper consonant is unclear but resembles n.
After this word, KR prints an asterisk in round parentheses. He may perhaps have wished to indicate that the visarga is supplied.
The characters shown here as unclear are in round parentheses in KR's edition. Elsewhere he also uses square brackets, apparently to indicate unclear, so something else may be the case here.
This word is in square brackets in KR's edition.
KR uses round parentheses with an asterisk here.

KR prints the supplied characters in square brackets with an asterisk. If I am correct in assuming that no characters are present here in the original, then I have strong reservations about supplying this. I am not sure of my understanding of the following words (see the translation), but given that KR's summary speaks about Vijayāditya II “destroying the Gāṅga race root and branch like a fierce wind,” probably referring to this locus, I believe KR too did not understand this passage clearly. I would expect another comparison with iva here; given māruta, the object of the comparison may be Indra. Unless perhaps we have a single long comparison here, and mahā-vratin above means Rudra.

KR shows ṭa in round parentheses with an asterisk, probably indicating a scribal omission. I provisionally accept his restoration because I do not have a clearly better solution, but I cannot make good sense of the word in context and other restorations may well be possible, including supplying a syllable before bha.
Though printed as clear by KR, this reading seems doubtful to me. Note also the sandhi at the end of the second pāda.
I provisionally accept KR's emendation, but believe that śrī is at least as likely to have been the composer's intent.
Round parentheses and asterisk in KR.
This should perhaps be read as, or emended to, yuddhe.
The characters shown as unclear are in round parentheses in KR's edition. He does not supply anusvāra, printing this stretch of text without spaces, but I assume he must have interpreted it as I do.

The second kari is hypermetrical and so, if it is present at all in the original, is probably dittography. But KR emends it to kara in his edition. He cites this stanza in full in his discussion, there printing karikari without emendation. See also the next note.

I cannot make sense of KR's emendation, which is identical in his edition and in the citation of this stanza in his text, except that in the edition the emendation is susthī, which is unmetrical and thus evidently a typo. See also the previous note. My own emendation is tenuous and may well be wrong; see the translation for my interpretation.

I have strong doubts that this word is present in the text. KR prints it both in his edition and in the stanza cited in his discussion; he moreover emends it in the edition to Bhāgavata (the only difference from the text being that the text is in Devanagari, and the emendation in the footnote is in transliteration, with a capital initial). This makes me wonder if the text in fact has bhāva-gata, which, even if slightly awkward, would make good sense in the context. Venturing further from the edition's text, I could imagine nagna-naṭa here; compare dīnānātha-nagna-naṭa-gāyaka-dharmma-dhvaja-vr̥ttīnāM in line 31 of the Eḍeru plates of Amma I and dīnānātha-naṭāndha-nagna-kavi- in line 39 of the Ārumbāka grant of Bādapa.
The characters shown as unclear are in square brackets in KR's edition.

If the reading is correct, then this is probably the parsing intended by the composer. KR prints a space after bhujā and nowhere else in this segment. Even with the words resolved, I am unable to interpret the line.

div.p: First reported and edited by K. V. Lakshmana Rao (posthumous publication curated by M. Somasekhara Sarma) in Bhārati, Vol. I, No. 1, pp. 90 ff., not traced. Edited by B. V. Krishna Rao () from inked impressions, without facsimiles and without translation. The present edition by Dániel Balogh follows Krishna Rao unless otherwise noted.
